ground_truth: The scene unfolds in the dimly lit station, where the camera angle restricts our view. A sergeant is positioned on the station's low sloping roof, and nearby, the captain sharply addresses two of his detail. He slowly turns his head, mouth agape, surveying the scene before him. The platform is densely packed with waiting crowds, extending from the station house and onto the narrow street lined with homes, their rooftops teeming with men, women holding babies, and children. As Gandhi disembarks from the train, guided by Shukla with Ba and Charlie a step behind, he moves through the silent crowd, hands in the pranam, bowing slightly. The crowd parts quietly, their clothing indicating a Muslim area, some offering a salaam or tentatively returning the pranam to Gandhi as he passes. Faces in the crowd appear gaunt and lean. Suddenly, a commotion arises; the sound of boots precedes the English captain as he pushes through to face Gandhi in the aisle formed by the crowd. The sergeant and part of the detail follow behind the captain, who stares before glancing suspiciously at the crowd with a hint of inner fear, then back at Gandhi. There's a flicker of uncertain recognition before another authoritative glance at the crowd. The captain, shaken by Gandhi's composed demeanor, glances at Charlie standing behind Gandhi, which further undermines his confidence. Attempting severity, the captain's demeanor falters, his weak authority evident. Unsettled by Gandhi's steady gaze, he looks at Charlie again, feeling the emptiness of his own weakness. Finally, he briskly turns, shoving past the crowd. Where silence once prevailed, excitement buzzes as Gandhi, having already won a subtle victory, continues forward, exchanging pranams with the crowd's warm greetings. The early sunlight bathes the scene, highlighting Meha, a middle-aged man appearing ill and drawn, lying on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The tableau unravels in the shadowy lit depot, where the lens viewpoint limits our sight. A constable is stationed on the depot's low inclined roof, and close by, the leader sharply addresses two of his unit. He gradually turns his head, mouth open, scanning the tableau before him. The platform is thickly filled with waiting throngs, stretching from the depot house and onto the narrow lane lined with dwellings, their rooftops brimming with individuals, women holding infants, and youngsters. As Gandhi alights from the locomotive, led by Shukla with Ba and Charlie a step behind, he advances through the mute throng, hands in the pranam, inclining slightly. The throng divides quietly, their garments indicating a Muslim zone, some offering a salaam or hesitantly returning the pranam to Gandhi as he proceeds. Visages in the throng seem haggard and slender. Abruptly, a disturbance emerges; the sound of footwear anticipates the English leader as he thrusts through to confront Gandhi in the corridor formed by the throng. The constable and part of the unit trail behind the leader, who gazes before looking distrustfully at the throng with a trace of inner trepidation, then back at Gandhi. There's a flicker of doubtful acknowledgment before another commanding look at the throng. The leader, unsettled by Gandhi's calm composure, looks at Charlie standing behind Gandhi, which further undermines his certainty. Trying sternness, the leader's composure falters, his frail dominance apparent. Unnerved by Gandhi's constant gaze, he looks at Charlie again, feeling the void of his own frailty. At last, he briskly pivots, pushing past the throng. Where silence once reigned, enthusiasm hums as Gandhi, having already achieved a subtle triumph, advances ahead, exchanging pranams with the throng's warm salutations. The early daylight illuminates the tableau, accentuating Meha, a middle-aged male appearing ill and emaciated, lying on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The scene is unfolded in the dimly lit station, where our view is restricted by the camera angle. The station's low sloping roof is occupied by a sergeant, and nearby, two of his detail are sharply addressed by the captain. His head is slowly turned, mouth agape, while the scene before him is surveyed. Waiting crowds densely pack the platform, extending from the station house and onto the narrow street lined with homes, their rooftops teem with men, women holding babies, and children. As the train is disembarked by Gandhi, guided by Shukla with Ba and Charlie a step behind, the silent crowd is moved through by him, hands in the pranam, bowing slightly. The crowd is quietly parted, their clothing indicates a Muslim area, some offer a salaam or tentatively return the pranam to Gandhi as he passes. Gaunt and lean faces appear in the crowd. Suddenly, a commotion is arisen; the sound of boots are preceded by the English captain as Gandhi is faced in the aisle formed by the crowd. The sergeant and part of the detail follow behind the captain, who stares before a suspicious glance is given at the crowd with a hint of inner fear, then back at Gandhi. A flicker of uncertain recognition occurs before another authoritative glance is given at the crowd. Gandhi's composed demeanor shakes the captain, Charlie is glanced at while standing behind Gandhi, which further undermines his confidence. Attempting severity, the captain falters, his weak authority is evident. Gandhi's steady gaze unsettles him, Charlie is looked at again, the emptiness of his own weakness is felt. Finally, he briskly turns, the crowd is shoved past. Where silence once prevailed, excitement is buzzed as Gandhi, having already won a subtle victory, continues forward, pranams are exchanged with the crowd's warm greetings. The early sunlight bathes the scene, Meha, a middle-aged man appearing ill and drawn, lies on a straw mat, and it is highlighted by it.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: In the dim station, our view is limited. A sergeant perches on the station's low roof as the captain sternly addresses two aides. He turns slowly, mouth agape, surveying the crowded platform spilling onto a narrow street lined with homes. As Gandhi alights, led by Shukla with Ba and Charlie behind, he moves through the silent crowd, hands in pranam, bowing slightly. The crowd, dressed in Muslim attire, quietly parts, some offering salaams or returning pranams. Faces are gaunt and lean. Suddenly, a commotion arises; boot sounds herald the English captain, who confronts Gandhi, followed by his detail. The captain's suspicious glance reveals inner fear. He recognizes Gandhi but is unsettled by his calm demeanor, further undermined by Charlie's presence. The captain's weak authority falters. He glances at Charlie, then briskly departs, shoving past the crowd. Excitement replaces silence as Gandhi, having subtly triumphed, moves forward, exchanging pranams amid warm greetings. Early sunlight bathes the scene, illuminating Meha, a sickly middle-aged man on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The dimly lit station scene reveals a restricted view. A sergeant sits on the sloping roof as a captain sharply addresses his detail, surveying the crowded platform and street lined with homes. Gandhi disembarks, guided by Shukla with Ba and Charlie, passing through a silent crowd, their attire indicating a Muslim area. Faces are gaunt, some offering salaams or pranams. A commotion arises as an English captain confronts Gandhi, his fear evident. Staring at Gandhi and Charlie, his weak authority falters. Turning abruptly, he shoves past the crowd. Excitement follows Gandhiâ€™s subtle victory as he exchanges pranams in the morning light, revealing Meha, ill on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The scene unfolds dramatically within the dimly illuminated confines of the railway station, where the restricted camera angle limits our perspective. Perched on the station's low, gently sloping roof is a sergeant, while nearby, the captain sharply addresses two members of his detail with authority. Slowly, the captain turns his head, mouth agape, surveying the full expanse of the scene unfolding before him. The bustling platform is densely packed with waiting crowds that extend from the station house out onto the narrow street, which is lined with homes whose rooftops are teeming with men, women holding babies, and curious children. As Gandhi disembarks from the train, he is gently guided by Shukla, with Ba and Charlie following a step behind. He moves gracefully through the silent crowd, his hands positioned in the pranam, bowing slightly in respect. The crowd parts quietly around him, their attire indicating that this is a Muslim area; some individuals offer a respectful salaam or tentatively return Gandhi's pranam as he passes by them. The faces within the crowd appear notably gaunt and lean, reflecting hardship. Suddenly, a commotion breaks the silence; the sound of heavy boots is heard as the English captain forcefully pushes his way through the gathered crowd to confront Gandhi in the aisle they have formed. The sergeant and part of the captain's detail follow closely behind him. The captain stares intently ahead before glancing around suspiciously at the crowd, a hint of inner fear apparent, before he turns his gaze back to Gandhi. There is a flicker of uncertain recognition in his eyes before he casts another authoritative glance at the crowd. The captain, visibly shaken by Gandhi's composed demeanor, glances insecurely at Charlie, who stands behind Gandhi, further undermining his confidence. Attempting to project severity, the captain's demeanor falters, his weak authority becoming evident. Unsettled by Gandhi's steady and unwavering gaze, he looks again at Charlie, acutely feeling the emptiness of his own weakness. Finally, he turns abruptly, brusquely shoving past the silent crowd. Where silence once prevailed, an undercurrent of excitement soon buzzes through the air as Gandhi, having already achieved a subtle victory, continues his forward movement, exchanging pranams with the crowd, who warmly greet him in return. The early morning sunlight bathes the entire scene, casting a warm glow and highlighting Meha, a middle-aged man who appears ill and drawn, lying on a simple straw mat.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The dramatic scene unfolds within the dimly illuminated confines of the railway station, where our view is limited by the restricted angle of the camera. Perched precariously on the station's low, gently sloping roof is a vigilant sergeant. Nearby, commanding attention, the captain sharply addresses two members of his detail with a tone of authority. Slowly, the captain turns his head, his mouth agape in disbelief as he surveys the full, expansive tableau unfolding before him. The bustling platform is densely packed with waiting crowds, a sea of humanity that stretches seamlessly from the station house out onto the narrow street. This street is lined with homes, their rooftops teeming like ant hills with men, women tenderly holding babies, and curious children. As Gandhi disembarks from the train, he is gently guided and supported by Shukla, with Ba and Charlie closely following, just a step behind. Gandhi moves with grace and composure through the silent crowd, his hands respectfully positioned in the pranam, bowing slightly as a gesture of respect. The crowd parts quietly around him, their attire clearly indicating that this is a predominantly Muslim area; some individuals offer a respectful salaam or tentatively return Gandhi's pranam as he reverently passes by them. The faces within the crowd appear notably gaunt and lean, a reflection of their ongoing hardship and struggles. Suddenly, a commotion disrupts the silence; the heavy, authoritative sound of boots reverberates as the English captain forcefully pushes his way through the assembled crowd to confront Gandhi in the aisle they have formed. The sergeant and part of the captain's detail follow closely in his wake. The captain stares intently straight ahead before glancing around suspiciously at the crowd, a hint of inner fear momentarily breaking through, before he turns his gaze back to Gandhi. There is a flicker of uncertain recognition in his eyes before he casts another authoritative glance at the gathered crowd. The captain, visibly shaken and disconcerted by Gandhi's composed demeanor, glances insecurely at Charlie, who stands behind Gandhi, further undermining the captain's fragile confidence. Attempting to project severity, the captain's demeanor falters, his weak authority becoming increasingly evident. Unsettled by Gandhi's steady and unwavering gaze, he looks once more at Charlie, acutely feeling the emptiness and inadequacy of his own weakness. Finally, he turns abruptly, brusquely shoving his way through the silent crowd once more. Where silence once dominated the atmosphere, an undercurrent of excitement soon buzzes through the air as Gandhi, having already achieved a subtle victory, continues his forward movement. He exchanges pranams with the crowd, who warmly greet him with their own respectful gestures in return. The early morning sunlight bathes the entire scene, casting a warm glow and highlighting Meha, a middle-aged man who appears ill and drawn, lying quietly on a simple straw mat, witnessing it all.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: In the dim light of the station, the constrained camera angle limits our vision, focusing our attention on a sergeant positioned on the station's low, sloping roof, observing the scene around him. Nearby, the captain, standing with a commanding presence, sharply addresses two of his detail. As he speaks, he deliberately turns his head, his mouth slightly agape as his eyes sweep over the unfolding scene, taking in the densely packed platform where a crowd awaits. This crowd extends outward from the station house and spills onto the narrow street, which is lined with homes whose rooftops are crowded with men, women holding babies, and children peering down. The moment Gandhi steps off the train, guided attentively by Shukla with Ba and Charlie trailing just behind, he begins to weave his way through the silent assemblage. His hands are held together in the pranam gesture, and he bows his head slightly in reverence. As he moves, the crowd gently parts around him, a silent acknowledgment of respect that reflects their attire signifying a Muslim area. Some within the crowd offer a salaam or tentatively reciprocate Gandhi's pranam as he moves past them, their faces gaunt and lean as they watch. Suddenly, a commotion breaks the tranquility; the sound of boots heralds the arrival of the English captain, who forcefully pushes his way through the throng until he stands face-to-face with Gandhi in the aisle that the crowd has formed. The sergeant and a portion of the detail trail closely behind him. The captain's eyes fix on Gandhi, before his gaze shifts suspiciously to the surrounding crowd, a fleeting hint of inner fear flickering within. He then looks back at Gandhi, a flicker of uncertain recognition crossing his features before he authoritatively surveys the crowd once more. Shaken by Gandhi's serene and composed demeanor, the captain's eyes stray to Charlie standing resolutely behind Gandhi, a sight that further undermines his confidence. In an attempt to project severity, the captain's facade falters, his injured authority painfully evident. Gandhi's steady, unwavering gaze unsettles him further, prompting the captain to glance again at Charlie, feeling the stark emptiness of his own weakness. In the end, he abruptly turns on his heel, briskly shoving past the crowd. Where silence had reigned, a buzzing excitement now fills the air as Gandhi, having already secured a subtle triumph, presses forward, continuing to exchange pranams with the crowd that greets him warmly. The scene is bathed in the soft glow of early sunlight, casting light on Meha, a middle-aged man whose illness is apparent in his drawn appearance as he lies on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The scene unfolds in the dimly lit station, where limited camera angles restrict the view. The sergeant is positioned on the station's low roof, while the captain sharply addresses his detail and surveys the crowded platform and street, densely packed with people, including men, women with babies, and children on rooftops. As Gandhi disembarks, led by Shukla with Ba and Charlie in tow, he moves through the silent crowd, hands in pranam, bowing slightly, as the predominantly Muslim crowd quietly parts, offering salaams or returning the gesture. Faces appear gaunt. Suddenly, the English captain, accompanied by his detail, strides through to confront Gandhi. He scrutinizes the crowd before regarding Gandhi with suspicious fear, flickering with uncertain recognition. Shaken by Gandhiâ€™s composed demeanor and Charlie's presence, the captain's false severity falters, exposing his weak authority. Overwhelmed and unsettled, he hastily retreats, pushing past the crowd. As excitement buzzes in the aftermath of Gandhi's subtle victory, he continues exchanging pranams amidst warm greetings from the crowd. The early sunlight illuminates Meha, a middle-aged man, looking ill and drawn on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The scene unfolds in the dimly lit station, a typical colonial-era railway terminal designed with scarce lighting, where the camera angle restricts our view. A sergeant, part of the British colonial forces tasked with maintaining order, is positioned on the station's low sloping roof, strategizing for potential threats, and nearby, the captain sharply addresses two of his detail with the customary severity expected of colonial officers. He slowly turns his head, mouth agape, surveying the scene before him, overwhelmed by the diversity of the crowd. The platform is densely packed with waiting crowds, extending from the station house and onto the narrow street lined with homes typical of the early 20th-century Indian architecture, their rooftops teeming with men, women holding babies, and children. As Gandhi, the prominent leader of the Indian independence movement known for his philosophy of nonviolence, disembarks from the train, guided by Shukla, an advocate for peasants in Champaran, with Ba, Gandhiâ€™s supportive wife, and Charlie, a sympathetic British ally, a step behind, he moves through the silent crowd, hands in the pranam, a traditional Hindu gesture of greeting, bowing slightly. The crowd parts quietly, their clothing indicating a Muslim area known for its vibrant intermingling of cultures, some offering a salaam, a respectful Islamic greeting, or tentatively returning the pranam to Gandhi as he passes. Faces in the crowd appear gaunt and lean, reflecting the widespread poverty stemming from colonial exploitation. Suddenly, a commotion arises; the sound of boots, symbolic of British military authority, precedes the English captain as he pushes through to face Gandhi in the aisle formed by the crowd. The sergeant and part of the detail follow behind the captain, who stares before glancing suspiciously at the crowd with a hint of inner fear, then back at Gandhi, whose presence challenges the empire's control. There's a flicker of uncertain recognition as the captain realizes Gandhi's growing influence before another authoritative glance at the crowd. The captain, shaken by Gandhi's composed demeanor that reflects his inner strength and resolve, glances at Charlie, a rare British supporter of Indian autonomy, standing behind Gandhi, which further undermines his confidence. Attempting severity, the captain's demeanor falters, his weak authority evident, as he struggles to exert control over the situation. Unsettled by Gandhi's steady gaze, he looks at Charlie again, feeling the emptiness of his own weakness brought on by years of unquestioned power. Finally, he briskly turns, shoving past the crowd. Where silence once prevailed, excitement buzzes as Gandhi, having already won a subtle victory through his nonviolent presence, continues forward, exchanging pranams with the crowd's warm greetings. The early sunlight, a metaphor for the new dawn of change, bathes the scene, highlighting Meha, a middle-aged man appearing ill and drawn, lying on a straw mat, symbolizing the suffering of millions under colonial rule.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The narrative unfolds in the brightly illuminated meadow, where the quirky lighting expands our perspective. A juggler is perched on the meadow's tall rolling hill, and nearby, the baker gently scolds two of his apprentices. He quickly shakes his hand, ears perked up, analyzing the spectacle beyond him. The garden is sparsely dotted with playful animals, stretching from the greenhouse and onto the wide path bordered with statues, their surfaces bustling with birds, bunnies clutching carrots, and squirrels. As the lion leaps from the wagon, led by Turner with Max and Danny a pace behind, he maneuvers through the lively animals, paws in a gesture of peace, nodding quietly. The animals scatter noisily, their behavior signaling a festive gathering spot, some offering a nod or cautiously echoing the peace gesture to the lion as he strides. Snouts in the garden look bright and cheery. Suddenly, a disturbance erupts; the sound of wings heralds the French baker as he flutters through to meet the lion in the lane crafted by the animals. The juggler and part of the apprentices trail behind the baker, who glares before peering warily at the animals with a trace of inner curiosity, then back at the lion. There's a flicker of curious awareness before another decisive peek at the animals. The baker, puzzled by the lion's calm presence, glances at Danny standing behind the lion, which further shakes his assurance. Struggling for composure, the baker's presence diminishes, his fragile confidence clear. Unperturbed by the lion's steady posture, he gazes at Danny again, sensing the depth of his own hesitation. Finally, he hastily spins, flitting past the animals. Where calmness once settled, delight hums as the lion, having already secured a subtle triumph, advances onward, exchanging peaceful gestures with the animals' cheerful salutations. The morning moonlight adorns the scene, accentuating Juno, an elderly turtle appearing brisk and spry, reclining on a leaf bed.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit station, a sergeant stands on a low roof as the captain sharply addresses his detail and surveys the densely packed platform. Gandhi disembarks from the train, accompanied by Shukla, Ba, and Charlie, and moves through the silent, predominantly Muslim crowd, exchanging pranams. Faces in the crowd are gaunt, and some respond with salaams. Suddenly, the English captain makes his way through the crowd to confront Gandhi, eyeing the crowd with suspicion and a hint of fear. The captain feels unsettled by Gandhi's composed demeanor and Charlie's presence behind him. Attempting to assert authority, the captain's confidence wavers, and he moves away, leaving Gandhi with a subtle victory. As excitement replaces silence, Gandhi continues forward, warmly greeted by the crowd. The early sunlight highlights Meha, a middle-aged man appearing ill, lying on a straw mat.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: The early sunlight bathes the scene highlighting Meha a middleaged man appearing ill and drawn lying on a straw mat Where silence once prevailed excitement buzzes as Gandhi having already won a subtle victory continues forward exchanging pranams with the crowd's warm greetings Finally he briskly turns shoving past the crowd Unsettled by Gandhi's steady gaze he looks at Charlie again feeling the emptiness of his own weakness Attempting severity the captain's demeanor falters his weak authority evident The captain shaken by Gandhi's composed demeanor glances at Charlie standing behind Gandhi which further undermines his confidence There is a flicker of uncertain recognition before another authoritative glance at the crowd The sergeant and part of the detail follow behind the captain who stares before glancing suspiciously at the crowd with a hint of inner fear then back at Gandhi the sound of boots precedes the English captain as he pushes through to face Gandhi in the aisle formed by the crowd Suddenly a commotion arises Faces in the crowd appear gaunt and lean The crowd parts quietly their clothing indicating a Muslim area some offering a salaam or tentatively returning the pranam to Gandhi as he passes As Gandhi disembarks from the train guided by Shukla with Ba and Charlie a step behind he moves through the silent crowd hands in the pranam bowing slightly The platform is densely packed with waiting crowds extending from the station house and onto the narrow street lined with homes their rooftops teeming with men women holding babies and children He slowly turns his head mouth agape surveying the scene before him A sergeant is positioned on the station's low sloping roof and nearby the captain sharply addresses two of his detail The scene unfolds in the dimly lit station where the camera angle restricts our view
